stream_context.summary: Kaze worked live on Course 1, replacing simple coin pick-ups with three ‘tutorial bunnies’.  Each bunny now spawns a visual prompt (button billboard plus rotating particle ring) after dialogue, demonstrating a specific move (mid-air dive, wall-slide → wall-kick, spin-jump).  Kaze iterated on shading, textures, camera logic and particle code, while Biobak supplied graphic feedback and Zeina showed an early animation clip.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 received visual tweaks: stronger shading, new wood texture for the windmill, additional shadows on mushrooms and props.
Three tutorial bunnies are being added to teach dive-jump, wall-kick/slide, and spin-jump; each rewards a coin after the move is performed.
development_findings.quote: Basically, we're going to add these tutorial bunnies to Course 1 that are going to teach you the movements.

development_findings.summary: Billboard prompts showing controller buttons (Z→A, A→A, Z→B) appear only after the player talks to a bunny, preventing confusion before interaction.
development_findings.quote: I feel like they should only be there after you talk to the bunny because I wouldn't want people to try to interact with them beforehand.

development_findings.summary: Prompts use pre-baked 64×64 indexed textures (16 colours, alpha 0/1) to respect N64 memory; gradients and high-res art were rejected.
development_findings.quote: The N64 on 64×64 images can only have 16 colors and transparency.

development_findings.summary: Particle rings now illustrate the target spot; two concentric circles of sprite particles rotate at slightly different speeds for clarity.
development_findings.quote: Oh, that's very nice … star particles around the circle.

development_findings.summary: Cut-scene code was adjusted so the camera stays stable; Kaze avoids automatic camera spins to preserve player control.
development_findings.quote: If you make the camera rotate without the player being able to predict it, you're always going to have the player hold a direction they don't intend.

development_findings.summary: Climbable surfaces were flagged where Mario lands so wall-slides slow down, making the coin challenge easier for newcomers.
development_findings.quote: This right here needs to be climbable … climbable surfaces in this game are programmed so that when you wall slide on them you slide slower.

development_findings.summary: Recent optimisation pass on sine/cosine functions and I-cache code blocks was mentioned, aiming for consistent 60 FPS on real hardware.
development_findings.quote: I've done some more optimizations to the sine and cosine functions recently.

development_findings.summary: Engine upgrades are ‘mostly done’; Kaze estimates overall progress at ~70 %, with level content still the main workload.
development_findings.quote: All the engine upgrades are done now mostly … we're getting close to finish … about 70 percent maybe.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refuses to offload coding to ChatGPT and stresses manual control of quality.
development_findings.quote: I'm not letting ChatGPT program my romhack. Are you crazy?

context_findings.summary: Kaze is evaluating a switch from Twitch to YouTube due to intrusive ads and exclusivity rules.
context_findings.quote: Twitch forces you to run an ad every 30 minutes … I decided, hey, let's test out YouTube.

context_findings.summary: He believes rom-hack players have limited patience because they paid nothing; tutorials must be concise.
context_findings.quote: With a romhack you have the disadvantage that no one paid for your game, so there's no initial commitment from the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze sees game development as a cycle that begins fun and becomes ‘pure torture’, advising newcomers to start small.
context_findings.quote: It always starts like really fun and eventually it turns into pure torture … start with a small project otherwise they are just going to not get anything done at all.

context_findings.summary: He notes legal risk: previous hacks (e.g., Climate Change 64) were DMCA’d; source code of RTYI will be open once released.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo took it down … It will be open source once it releases.

context_findings.summary: Personal: Kaze streams next to workout equipment; casual mention of regular lifting and shared workspace with Zeina.
context_findings.quote: That's actually what I did right before stream, I was just dead lifting 400 pounds there digitally.

biobak.summary: Gave real-time art feedback (grass edge shading too hard, Mario lighting too dark) and volunteered to rebuild billboard textures as a single material.
biobak.quote: Biobak, you get to make the billboards. You can make them even more understandable if you want.

zeina.summary: Showed an in-progress animation clip (Mario bounce/spin) and discussed pivot issues with Kaze.
zeina.quote: It looks a little like he's not rotating around his actual middle … I'm moving the root but it's tricky.

key_stories.title: Inventing the Tutorial Bunny System
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs a gentle yet optional way to teach new movement mechanics.  Initial idea was simple text and a reachable coin, but testers could bypass moves.  He iterated through billboard icons, cinematic bunny demonstrations, and finally particle rings that validate the correct move before rewarding a coin.
key_stories.challenge: Teach advanced moves without overwhelming or boring players.
key_stories.process: Tried static coin placement → feared skips; added button billboards → worried about confusion; built rotating particle rings that appear post-dialogue; coded camera, physics and climbable surfaces; refined textures with Biobak.
key_stories.outcome: A three-bunny system that visually demonstrates each move, spawns a clear ring, and rewards success—ready for Saturday animation pass.
key_stories.key_quote: If you guys look at this and you tell me you will not think to press Z and then A, I am going to be very upset.
